page.title: 04Flowers of Beeley Moor
page.content: {MOORLAND:-}this area has a high proportion of moorland between 300 - 370 metres above sea level. It is dominated by heather and the cross leaved heath with cowberry, bilberry and their hybrid being common. The soil is mainly peat overlying gritstone. In the sick (damp areas), harestail cotton grass, blue moorgrass, deersedge, soft rush spagnum moss and very occasionally, sundew are found. Along the road are monkshood and pink lupin. {HIPPER VALLEY:-}this valley which drops to 240 metres above sea level, has a wider variety of plants including the downy birch, the great marsh thistle, harebell, foxglove, hedge parsley, scabious, belony, marsh bedstraw, tufted vetch, marsh orchid, marsh penneywort, leadwort, monks rhubarb, bracken and ox-eye daisy.
